paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Become familiar with using Spark MLlib to run Linear Regression for use in classification on Hadoop
**File locations:** spark-labs/weatherAUS.csv
**Successful outcome:** A trained linear classifier that predicts if it will rain tomorrow
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Supervised learning, Linear regression

---

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the data from internet and store it in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

rm -f weatherAUS.csv
wget -nc -P /home/zeppelin https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/rattle-togaware-weather/weatherAUS.csv
hdfs dfs -rm spark-labs/weatherAUS.csv
hdfs dfs -put weatherAUS.csv spark-labs/

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler, StringIndexer
from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import MulticlassClassificationEvaluator as MCE

%md
First we need to load the data into a dataframe using the 'header' and 'inferSchema' options.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load the data into a Spark DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%md
When doing machine learning, it is important to look at the data you are working with
Use z.show(data) to view the first 20 rows of your data

paragraphs.title: 2 - Inspect the data

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Transform the DataFrame into one usable by Spark ML

Spark contains many helper functions, like StringIndexer to convert categorical variables to numerical ones.
We will define a function process_data that does all this, and then assembles the data for us.

%md

Copy and paste the code below in the next paragraph
~~~
def process_data(data):    
    non_null = data.na.drop(how="any")
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindGustDir',outputCol = 'WindGustDir_indexed')
    indexed1 = indexer.fit(non_null).transform(non_null)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir9am', outputCol = 'WindDir9am_indexed')
    indexed2 = indexer.fit(indexed1).transform(indexed1)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir3pm', outputCol = 'WindDir3pm_indexed')
    indexed3 = indexer.fit(indexed2).transform(indexed2)
    
    indexed = indexed3.drop('WindGustDir','WindDir9am','WindDir3pm')
    
    feature_columns = list(filter(lambda x: 'Temp' in x or 'WindGust' in x or '9am' in x or '3pm' in x,indexed.columns))

    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_columns, outputCol="features")

    # Transform the data into a form useable by SParkML
    vectorized = assembler.transform(indexed)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = "RainTomorrow", outputCol = 'label')
    labeled  = indexer.fit(vectorized).transform(vectorized)
    return labeled
~~~

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create the process_data function

paragraphs.text:
%md

In the next cell, call process_data on the data we read in.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Call the process_data on our data

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
This is the data that we will feed to our machine learning algorithm.

%md
Next we need to split this data between a training and a testing set.
We will keep 
* 80% of the rows for training and save the other 20% for testing on and
* use a seed of 228 that will help everyone in the class have similar results.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Split the data into training and test instances
7 - Create an object of the class LinearRegression with the default parameters

paragraphs.text:
%md

Now we can train the model on the training data. This may take a few seconds to run.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Train the model on the training data

paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the trained model to make predictions on the test data by calling the 'transform' transformation of the model on the test data.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Use the model to make predictions

paragraphs.text:
%md
The last dataframe now has an extra prediction column
We can compare the prediction to the label of a few of the rows in the test set

paragraphs.title: 10 - Compare the labels and the predictions

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice how the prediction is a continuous variable as we are using regression.
Use the following code to set anything that is greater than or equal to 0.5 to 1, and everything else to 0
~~~
predictions = predictions.withColumn("prediction", (predictions['prediction'] >= 0.5).cast('double'))
~~~

paragraphs.title: 11 - Convert the predictions to binary labels
12 - Compare the labels and the predictions again

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create an MulticlassClassificationEvaluator (MCE) object and print out the F1 measure
~~~
evaluator = MCE()
print(evaluator.evaluate(predictions))
~~~
You should see a value of 0.832395728182447

paragraphs.title: 13 - Create an MCE object and print out the F1 measure

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can use Zeppelin's built in features to visualize our labels and predictions.

1. Visualize the predictions dataframe 
2. Use the pivot table feature 
3. Choose the scatter plot visualization
4. Experiment charting different features against each other
5. Use either the label or the prediction columns as the group variable

paragraphs.title: 14 - Visualize the predictions

paragraphs.title: Bonus
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you have extra time, try to improve your model.
* Combine the assembler and regressor into a Pipeline
* Go back to step #3 in the notebook and change the columns included as features
* What happens if we included the binary variable RainToday
* After editing that cell, run the entire notebook again by hitting the play button at the top

%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now successfully trained a linear model for classification and evaluated it using the F1 score.

---

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create the process_data function
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

def process_data(data):    
    non_null = data.na.drop(how="any")
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindGustDir',outputCol = 'WindGustDir_indexed')
    indexed1 = indexer.fit(non_null).transform(non_null)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir9am', outputCol = 'WindDir9am_indexed')
    indexed2 = indexer.fit(indexed1).transform(indexed1)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = 'WindDir3pm', outputCol = 'WindDir3pm_indexed')
    indexed3 = indexer.fit(indexed2).transform(indexed2)
    
    indexed = indexed3.drop('WindGustDir','WindDir9am','WindDir3pm')
    
    feature_columns = list(filter(lambda x: 'Temp' in x or 'WindGust' in x or '9am' in x or '3pm' in x,indexed.columns))

    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_columns, outputCol="features")

    # Transform the data into a form useable by SParkML
    vectorized = assembler.transform(indexed)
    indexer = StringIndexer(inputCol = "RainTomorrow", outputCol = 'label')
    labeled  = indexer.fit(vectorized).transform(vectorized)
    return labeled

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
